Posts.Title: Stepdad diagnosed with Aggressive Cancer but have questions

Posts.Content: Consult1,Physical therapy help me I had really little issues with control within a month of the surgery.But still leaked I was great by the third month. I when back to work (letter carrier USPS) and found any lifting cause leakage. I was giving help the first month and the leakage has been better. I am 26 months out of surgery and this time of year with the holiday rush I'm once again on a mini pad. The leak just happens without notice,but it always happens with any lift over 10 lbs. Being 8 months into ADT my muscle structure is about gone, testosterone is <6 I ache all over and working 12 hour days does not help. The good news is I have my 30 years and can leave any time. Was hoping to make it to 60th BD in 14 months. steve

Posts.Title: Well, Now What?

Posts.Content: Sorry for not explaining completely the requirements to get in the trial are medical, such as PSA levels at time recurrence,age, not having treatments is one also. The delay in treatment will be about 11 days. This trial has resulted in finding the cancer recurrence many times is NOT in the prostate bed. Which salvage Radiation to the bed would have cause a 2 month delay. I met with the oncologist and she felt the short delay wasn't a big issue. The trial is two visits once on Friday the 17th and then 6 months later to see the results. On Monday the 19th I start the radiation therapy. If its found not to be in the Bed then they will need to change the plans. If it is in the Bed they will have a visual of the actual site with a size and shape. I am comfortable with the delay. The doctors feelings are its recurred very aggressive like the first and if we miss it by point and hope we hit something, the trial was a good idea in my case. one of the his trials candidate found the spot just outside the bed area and may not have had good results without first seeing. steve

Posts.Title: 16 Month Recurrence from 0 to .4

Posts.Content: Mike Thanks for the information helps me out to relax. I'm good now no need to hook me up with anyone right now. Just good to know I have support. steve Originally Posted by Michael F Welcome Steve! The Auxumin Trial resulted in it being cleared by the FDA to identify/locate recurrent PC. If you are in fact being offered enrollment into a continuing investgative trial keep in mind that you may be randomized and thus will only have a 50% chance of being in the Auxumin wing of the trial. 5 years ago, I was "worked up" at Emory to enroll in an Auxumin trial. Since my PSA was < 0.05ng/ml I did not qualify. Chuck & Jim: The Auxumin wing includes a PET scan to detect areas of recurrence. Only those areas get "focally" radiated. The non Auxumin wing receives the standard radiation protocol for recurrent PC (the entire prostate bed). Thus Steve will likely receive radiation fairly soon. A "silent" Forum Brother experienced a rising PSA and had the Auxumin PET scan. It found an inconclusive lymph node that the MDs deemed suspicious. This led to a CT guided Bx of the node last Monday. If (+) he will receive 40 treatments that focus on the node (and likely some neighboring geography) Steve: I can put you in touch with him. Good luck. Hope they pinpoint locate the culprit & then pinpoint destroy it! MF

Posts.Title: 16 Month Recurrence from 0 to .4

Posts.Content: First post just found the site, looks like a great bunch of people helping others. Thanks. As posted after radical 10/2015 my first indication was .4 at the 16 month mark a retest 2 weeks later same lab same test .5 oh boy! See my signature for more info. Since I already had a bench mark for Pet Bone Scan where I had a questionable spot a retest was ordered, all uptake and they are quite sure at this time its clear. I understand the normal process is to salvage radiate the Prostate bed along with hormone therapy, which is good since my Prostate had area on one side that may have been a hole. I've met with the oncologist for the radiation treatments will proceed depending on Results of Trial Study I've been invited to participate. The trial study is Blue-Earth-Diagnostics they have had some good results in locating the recurrence location with the use of a radioisotope F18 and use of a Pet Scan. (Short version) This study in the USA is only in 10 states and a total of 330 men will participate in this study. There are a bunch of bench marks you must meet and there are pros and cons to entering. One was they have located other cancers not related to the prostate. I am scheduled 3/17/2017 for this trial and then they can plan the radiation based on the results. Here are some links both from Blue earth and Feds! http://www.businesswire.com/news/hom...xumin%E2%84%A2 https://clinicaltrials.gov/ct2/resul...&Search=Search https://clinicaltrials.gov/ct2/show/...e+earth&rank=2 Hoping the info I have provided helps others. steve EDIT: ACCAULLY PSA 0.1 WAS AT 1 YEAR POST RADICAL 10/06/2016 THEN CLIMED TO 0.4 02/02/2017

Posts.Content: First post just found the site, looks like a great bunch of people helping others. Thanks. As posted after radical 10/2015 my first indication was .4 at the 16 month mark a retest 2 weeks later same lab same test .5 oh boy! See my signature for more info. Since I already had a bench mark for Pet Bone Scan where I had a questionable spot a retest was ordered, all uptake and they are quite sure at this time its clear. I understand the normal process is to salvage radiate the Prostate bed along with hormone therapy, which is good since my Prostate had area on one side that may have been a hole. I've met with the oncologist for the radiation treatments will proceed depending on Results of Trial Study I've been invited to participate. The trial study is Blue-Earth-Diagnostics they have had some good results in locating the recurrence location with the use of a radioisotope F18 and use of a Pet Scan. (Short version) This study in the USA is only in 10 states and a total of 330 men will participate in this study. There are a bunch of bench marks you must meet and there are pros and cons to entering. One was they have located other cancers not related to the prostate. I am scheduled 3/17/2017 for this trial and then they can plan the radiation based on the results. Here are some links both from Blue earth and Feds! http://www.businesswire.com/news/hom...xumin%E2%84%A2 https://clinicaltrials.gov/ct2/resul...&Search=Search https://clinicaltrials.gov/ct2/show/...e+earth&rank=2 Hoping the info I have provided helps others. steve EDIT: ACCAULLY PSA 0.1 WAS AT 1 YEAR POST RADICAL 10/06/2016 THEN CLIMED TO 0.4 02/02/2017

Posts.Content: Sorry for not explaining completely the requirements to get in the trial are medical, such as PSA levels at time recurrence,age, not having treatments is one also. The delay in treatment will be about 11 days. This trial has resulted in finding the cancer recurrence many times is NOT in the prostate bed. Which salvage Radiation to the bed would have cause a 2 month delay. I met with the oncologist and she felt the short delay wasn't a big issue. The trial is two visits once on Friday the 17th and then 6 months later to see the results. On Monday the 19th I start the radiation therapy. If its found not to be in the Bed then they will need to change the plans. If it is in the Bed they will have a visual of the actual site with a size and shape. I am comfortable with the delay. The doctors feelings are its recurred very aggressive like the first and if we miss it by point and hope we hit something, the trial was a good idea in my case. one of the his trials candidate found the spot just outside the bed area and may not have had good results without first seeing. steve

Posts.Content: Mike Thanks for the information helps me out to relax. I'm good now no need to hook me up with anyone right now. Just good to know I have support. steve Originally Posted by Michael F Welcome Steve! The Auxumin Trial resulted in it being cleared by the FDA to identify/locate recurrent PC. If you are in fact being offered enrollment into a continuing investgative trial keep in mind that you may be randomized and thus will only have a 50% chance of being in the Auxumin wing of the trial. 5 years ago, I was "worked up" at Emory to enroll in an Auxumin trial. Since my PSA was < 0.05ng/ml I did not qualify. Chuck & Jim: The Auxumin wing includes a PET scan to detect areas of recurrence. Only those areas get "focally" radiated. The non Auxumin wing receives the standard radiation protocol for recurrent PC (the entire prostate bed). Thus Steve will likely receive radiation fairly soon. A "silent" Forum Brother experienced a rising PSA and had the Auxumin PET scan. It found an inconclusive lymph node that the MDs deemed suspicious. This led to a CT guided Bx of the node last Monday. If (+) he will receive 40 treatments that focus on the node (and likely some neighboring geography) Steve: I can put you in touch with him. Good luck. Hope they pinpoint locate the culprit & then pinpoint destroy it! MF

Posts.Title: Maybe nothing but its of concern to me and Uro PSA inching

Posts.Content: Quick review PCa found (56) at low PSA Prostate removed 10/17 (4+3) neg margins, pT3a,N0 . 1 year 4 months PSA raised very fast to .4 Aximun trial found 17.4mm recurrence near rt. semi vascular bed, semi vascular were neg. at removal. Did 42 SRT started ADT 3/29/17 SRT complete 6/3/17 first PSA <.1 Next six uPSA .006 Now I was told early on the the uPSA test were so sensitive and not to be concerned if the number varies from test to test, well that proved not to be true as each and every test was the same .006 for six test in a row. (18 months) I just had my 7th uPSA and I have had a movement to .03? which is six times what it was! Can't remember the 3rd digit. URO says he's concern because I'm still on ADT and that's not a small variance in movement he would expect to see? Just had last shot. He went on to say while still considered undetectable and super low reading and not to give too much concern yet. He feels it could of just been a glitch at this point. Next test in 3 months. I did Stop taken Casodex (bicalutamide) on 6/18, still 3 month later test was .006 but 6 months later .03 could that be the reason for the burp? Wife is on edge again will be for three months oh boy! What does this group feel at this time? Steve D

Posts.Title: Maybe nothing but its of concern to me and Uro PSA inching

Posts.Content: Quick review PCa found (56) at low PSA Prostate removed 10/17 (4+3) neg margins, pT3a,N0 . 1 year 4 months PSA raised very fast to .4 Aximun trial found 17.4mm recurrence near rt. semi vascular bed, semi vascular were neg. at removal. Did 42 SRT started ADT 3/29/17 SRT complete 6/3/17 first PSA <.1 Next six uPSA .006 Now I was told early on the the uPSA test were so sensitive and not to be concerned if the number varies from test to test, well that proved not to be true as each and every test was the same .006 for six test in a row. (18 months) I just had my 7th uPSA and I have had a movement to .03? which is six times what it was! Can't remember the 3rd digit. URO says he's concern because I'm still on ADT and that's not a small variance in movement he would expect to see? Just had last shot. He went on to say while still considered undetectable and super low reading and not to give too much concern yet. He feels it could of just been a glitch at this point. Next test in 3 months. I did Stop taken Casodex (bicalutamide) on 6/18, still 3 month later test was .006 but 6 months later .03 could that be the reason for the burp? Wife is on edge again will be for three months oh boy! What does this group feel at this time? Steve D

Posts.Title: My dad has a high PSA. I'm lost.

Posts.Content: Little background is in order. RALP Oct. 2015 Oct. 2016 PSA started to rise to .2 Three months later PSA .4 I know what your all thinking,something should have been done at .2 I believe my Urologist had a plan all along. He was the one of two trial studies at the time for a new drug that claimed to find PC in tissue and organs long before it showed as pain. They knew it was successful above 1.0 Half of the 330 positions had been used with men at .2 .3 and the results weren't showing promising. At .4 I enter the trial and by the time I got on the PET Scanner and had the drug trial I had reached .6 in a couple of weeks. The trial showed a 17.5 mm tumor being the most likely cause of the PSA This most likely from Perineural invasion. I then started 42 sessions of SR treatments with special attention to that spot in the rt. semi vascular bed ending in June of 2017 Today I received my first PSA results since ending SRT PSA .01 Which I'm told is zero. I'm so happy with my and doctors choices thus far in my treatment. Just waiting to get off the ADT treatment its really messing up sleep and my muscles feel like they aren't connected to my bones. I find it difficult at my work delivering mail,packages getting in and out of the truck going up stairs, 9/10 hours a day! Thanks for all who have helped me through my journey reading many of your post have kept me going. Hoping my good news gives other hope! Steve

Posts.Title: Update after 14 months

Posts.Content: The PSA test was not 0 it was <0.1 which really means not able to be determined by the specific test giving, but still less than .1 The uPSA testing goes beyond the normal testing out to 3 decimal points .000. I read some place the lowest measurement is .006 and even woman will measure at that level as they have PSA in breast milk and female ejaculation. It is now clear that the term prostate-specific antigen is a misnomer: it is an antigen but is not specific to the prostate. Although present in large amounts in prostatic tissue and semen, it has been detected in other body fluids and tissues. So zero is just a figure of speech my doctor said zero for a year plus when it actually read <.1 the next test was >.4 and then all hell broke loose. I believe had the uPSA been give all along he would have seen the raise in PSA from 3 months on. I believe also this was an eye opener for him as well! In all my research this has become MHO. steve

Posts.Content: Jeff congrats on the zero club, like mention above keep on the Dr's with the PSA test. Ask about uPsa I believe it is the way to go many don't like that it can move from test to test and scare some? Do some research on seminal vesicle invasion I recall reading that's not a good at all! ED was the last thing on my mind and still is. Breathing was and is the very most important to me and my wife... steve

Posts.Title: 8 month post surgery, still in the zero club

Posts.Content: Mary, So sorry to see possible recurrence. You didn't mention any meds.? Just the thought of recurrence will change his energy/fatigue levels, the mind is so powerful. I followed a similar path very aggressive PC. Recurrence only one year out from removal. I did a trial study to find the recurrence area and was glad I did as it wasn't located in the normal location, (prostate bed). I am quite sure the Axumin pet scan is now coded in most insurances. Its quite costly otherwise! It was able to locate my PC and hence Radiation followed. My first PSA 3 months since radiation was undetectable. I just did the second 6 month awaiting results, Dec.1 It may be worth asking your doctor about Axumin Pet Scanning. LINK DELETED BY MODERATOR BECAUSE IT LINKS TO A PRODUCT. PLEASE SEE BELOW -- CHUCK Good luck steve MODERATOR'S NOTE: While it is against forum rules to link to a product, I believe Steve's intention was to offer info on it. So I will copy-paste the text down below without exposing the contact info: INDICATION Axumin (fluciclovine F 1 injection is indicated for positron emission tomography (PET) imaging in men with suspected prostate cancer recurrence based on elevated blood prostate specific antigen (PSA) levels following prior treatment. IMPORTANT SAFETY INFORMATION Image interpretation errors can occur with Axumin PET imaging. A negative image does not rule out recurrent prostate cancer and a positive image does not confirm its presence. The performance of Axumin seems to be affected by PSA levels. Axumin uptake may occur with other cancers and benign prostatic hypertrophy in primary prostate cancer. Clinical correlation, which may include histopathological evaluation, is recommended. Hypersensitivity reactions, including anaphylaxis, may occur in patients who receive Axumin. Emergency resuscitation equipment and personnel should be immediately available. Axumin use contributes to a patient's overall long-term cumulative radiation exposure, which is associated with an increased risk of cancer. Safe handling practices should be used to minimize radiation exposure to the patient and health care providers. Adverse reactions were reported in 1% of subjects during clinical studies with Axumin. The most common adverse reactions were injection site pain, injection site erythema and dysgeusia.

Posts.Title: 2 years out

Posts.Content: Gunz, PSA is a funny thing while its really the only indicator (blood Test ) they have, the other test they preform (DRE) allows the doctor to make his decision. Many men have a very low PSA reading and they still find cancer? In my case moving from 1.5 to 2.0 then 2.4 they biopsy 5 out of 10 for cancer. I have a family history of PC so each of us is a different case. Get Dr. Walsh's book Surviving Prostate Cancer you don't need to read it cover to cover but the info you gain will go along way to help you understand your journey. steve

Posts.Title: PSA jumps By Four Points In Three Weeks.

Posts.Content: Mary, looks like a couple of weeks before the scans. Take the time to educate both you and your husband what the test and doctor will be talking about. My doctor is both annoyed and pleased when I understand his big words and quote more information than the patient should know. But in the two plus years he takes the time with me because I understand way too much more than,oh I have PC. It will both cause anxiety and relief knowing what's coming. Your able to say no or request different test if your able to show a reason, this can be good and bad. My Radiation Oncologist advised me not to waste time on the trial study about (3 weeks) since my PSA was raising about every 10 days by .1 In the end the location of my recurrence wasn't in the Prostate Bed as it often is and SRT is done, believe me I pointed this out to her on my pre-mapping day. I didn't get a response... Good Luck with the testing steve Side note: My PSA test came back .1 undetectable uPSA .006

Posts.Title: 2 years out

Posts.Content: Hey 46 I'm thinking 72 isn't that old? I assume you aren't in great shape now to give yourself a old guy rating? I'm thinking 85 is an old guy! I'm also thinking 2 years now of ADT/HT and RT is a good choice if warranted. No telling if you elected not to have the treatments how you'll feel or if you be feeling anything 10 years down the road. There is no hard and fast rules on PCa. Patients surprise doctors by exceeding there life expectancy on some chart, just as patients never reach there life expectancy on that same chart! I'm 59 and I'll take 72 at this point, but 85 is such a better number to me... Hang in there ask the right questions and make a informed decision by all the information you get.

Posts.Title: RALP Pathology Stage T3b, Gleason 9, Invasion of Seminal Vesticles. How bad is it?

Posts.Content: Gary I'm kinda in the same boat as you. I really don't like how I'm feeling with the ADT/HT treatments and I have about 7 months for two years. I work a full week 50 hrs. My understanding is the PCa cells that left the prostate have a chance to grow, but the ADT/HT lowers you Testosterone to zero which is needed to feed the PCa so it can't grow. I'm 59 and really wish to keep breathing at this time regardless of the way the drugs make me feel. I told the Uro if my PSA shows a trend to go up after I stop, I'm willing to take ADT/HT for life! I really don't want to give it a chance at all. Maybe your 85 years old and had enough...? I say throw the kitchen sink at it... steve

Posts.Title: Urine and ejaculation

Posts.Content: From previous thread "16 Month Recurrence from 0 to .4 " I delayed SRT by about 14 days waiting for Axumin trial. Good news bad news... The results showed the location of the recurrence just outside the prostate bed they would have radiated. At the distal rectosigmoid, a suspected malignant nodule on the right 17.5mm in size demonstrates intense uptake likely source of patients rising PSA. This is situated roughly in the right seminal vesicle bed, right seminal vesicle removed during prostatectomy. The way it was explained was while in the area of prostate bed it would have mostly been missed with standard SRT as its located tucked up under bladder! While I have not seen the oncologist since report the UR says it may require radiation through bladder and hitting rectum which is never good. Maybe she has better plan? UR said new study using injections that move bladder out of the way have been tried? Other previous area's from two pet scans are deemed no abnormalities whatsoever, no obvious malignancy. So I feel I made the right call at this point in my treatment options. For those who might want to used this new type source to locate PC recurrence here is what I know. You may be able to pay your own way. Most insurance won't pay at this writing. You'll have to foot the bill, the injection of drug is just under 4k, then the cost of pet scan, which I think was 6k on my insurance forms? There still may be openings in the trial I was in but only doing 330 test I think I was 0117. And your insurance can/may be canceled if you enter this trial study, I had to sign I agreed to knowing this. I had thought I heard Medicare will pay sometimes. I heard they were trying to get Axumin its own insurance code in hopes of more companies adding it on? Only 10 states doing trial. Here are some links both from Blue Earth and Feds! http://www.businesswire.com/news/hom...xumin%E2%84%A2 https://clinicaltrials.gov/ct2/resul...&Search=Search https://clinicaltrials.gov/ct2/show/...e+earth&rank=2 steve

Posts.Title: Dad newly diagnosed w/aggressive prostate cancer

Posts.Content: If there were lots of lab fluctuations at that level, then why would members here continually receive the same results without change. I am going on my 7th in a row with the same result of .006 My UR and myself also would have thought that it would fluctuate some what over the last two years. I've seen others post the same type results. To tell you the truth my UR didn't want to use the ultra sensitive psa test. But after my recurrence and how fast it went from <.1 to .4 in three months and then + .1 every two weeks, he felt it would give that added warning if started to move again. I'm quite happy with the ultra sensitive psa test. I have a good open relationship with my UR and he told me several times he's learned a lot with my case! From being told by insurance he couldn't use the drug of choice to have to use Triptorelin Pamoate which he confided in telling me he had not used before. But is quite happy with and has prescribed to several others since! I am thinking psa testing has come a long way in the last few years...

I had spend a couple of years doing a flow rate test, had a sigmoidoscopy determined nothing wrong with bladder or obstruction . It was about then the first rise in PSA occurred I had never had movement in PSA. My dad and grandfather both had PC another reason for the concern. steve

Posts.Title: For those on long term hormone therapy (ADT)

Posts.Content: PSA test is what they use for Prostate cancer its one part that's not perfect either. 4.0 was the number they had always treated as benchmark. In other countries its as high as 10.0. There are also other factors, like how fast it went from one test to another, if it keeps rising. DRE. Each person is different as is each doctor. Also its about insurance companies, they just won't pay for test till numbers are reached. With me going from 1.5 to 2.0 was odd 2.0 to 2.4 was odder. The doctor said insurance won't pay for biopsy till it goes higher. I told him but I will pay. Biopsy showed cancer. Submitted to insurance they paid. Now let us know what is you plan of attack keep us posted sorry to hear your here. steve

Posts.Title: Low PSA causes big trouble for me

Posts.Content: Since the C came back I've been on Casodex and Trelstar medications and I did radiation treatments. The first three PSA test post treatments have been less than .1 normal test, .006 on the ultra sensitive test two times. In talking with doctor about results the meds are some what masking the the PSA results. Does that mean keeping PSA at zero? Or does it mean they can't measure the real amount do to drugs? So is my PSA really .006 or something else that can't be seen through the drugs. This to make me mentally feel somethings working? I'm at best confused for the first time in this journey... steve

Uro total me that the testosterone wasn't going to come back too fast at age 60 anyhow. I have been all for making sure we give it a good effort to stop it from spreading. Posts.Content: Hi Ozarks, I'm with Highlander is there a compelling reason Not to offer Surgery? I would guess its the focal uptake in pelvic area?Ask for a better look at that area. I would ask questions still. 63 is kinda young not to be more aggressive with III 4+3 staging. I was thought to be T2 before surgery 4+4 but had the organ taken out and it was found to be 4+3 staged Pt3a,N0 Sure enough one year later it was found to have spread. I was 56 yrs old! Psa 2.4 steve
